head.title: Elegy I.1
head.note: 1 First published in Poetical Essays (1788), pp. 3-6.

lg.l: For rural shades and solitary groves,
I’ll bid the busy scenes of life farewell;
And go where lonely contemplation roves,

Pleas’d with the sweet Enthusiast22 That is, Music: “At last divine Cecilia came, / … / The sweet enthusiast, from her sacred store, / Enlarged the former narrow bounds”: John Dryden, Alexander’s Feast, or the Power of Music (1697), lines 167, 173. to dwell.
The mind of man is ever prone to change,
Is ever stretching after something new:
Pleasure the shadow after which we range,
And still the phantom flies as we pursue.
One, made the abject slave of sordid gain,
Unnumber’d schemes and artifices tries;
For this he braves the dangers of the main,
And barters quiet for the golden prize.
Some, whom the noble thoughts of glory fire,
Pursue, in martial fields, a deathless name,
And where unnumber’d multitudes expire,
They rear the purple column of their fame.

The meager student,33 “Beside a paly lamp, with bitten nails, the meagre student o’er a folio sits”: James Graeme, “A Night-Piece,” in his Poems on Several Occasions (Edinburgh: Donaldson, 1773), p. 30. by the lamp’s pale light,
Eager the depths of science to explore,
Deny’d the balmy blessings of the night,

Still turns the sapient volume44 “Enrag’d the rustic rout, with foul despight, / From Palinode the sapient volume tore,” from a short Spenserian poem in praise of Spenser in “To the Editor: Remarks on the Opinion of Dr. Johnson concerning the Imitation of Spenser,” Edinburgh Magazine or Literary Miscellany, VI (August, 1787), p. 50. Turnbull uses the phrase recurrently; cf. “The Vicissitudes of Fortune,” line 134, in Poetical Essays, “Elegy,” line 16, in Columbian Herald and New Daily Advertiser [Charleston, SC] (March 25, 1796) and “Epilogue,” line 11, in the same (April 1, 1796). o’er and o’er.
Obsequious, one to pleasure’s magic call,
The fleeting hours in revelry beguiles,
Conducts the blooming beauty through the ball,
And counts his treasures by his fair one’s smiles.
No thoughts of wealth my wishes e’er decoy,
I ne’er was fir’d with mighty feats of arms;
But love of quiet and serener joy,
Retir’d from busy crouds and wars alarms.
Be mine in simple melody to pour,

In Shenstone’s strains, the elegiac lay;55 Chiefly remembered for his Spenserian imitation, The School-Mistress (1737), the English poet and Jacobite sympathizer William Shenstone (1714-1763) wrote twenty-six elegies by 1748. See The Works in Verse and Prose, vol.1, ed. Dodsley (1764-1765).
Or, in the solemn silent midnight hour,

To mourn with thee, O sweet complaining Gray.66 Another of the English poets Turnbull recurrently cites is Thomas Gray (1716-1771): see “Elegy IX” in Poetical Essays (1788) and “Elegy” in Columbian Herald and New Daily Advertiser [Charleston, SC] (March 25, 1796). The London bookseller, poet and playwright Robert Dodsley, who had included Shenstone’s work in his Collection of Poems by Several Hands (1748), was the first publisher of Gray’s Elegy, in 1751 as a quarto pamphlet originally titled Elegy Wrote in a Country Churchyard.
Soft flow my numbers, and without constraint,
Smooth as the murmurs of a winding rill,
Let nature’s hand each beauteous fancy paint;
For nature’s images are charming still.
At early dawn, or at the close of day,
I’ll seek the paths inspired Bards have trode;

With Fancy, bright aerial maid,77“Where Fancy, bright aerial Maid, / Awaits thee with her thousand Charms”: Robert Lloyd, “Ode to Genius,” in Poetical Works, 2 vols. (London: Evans, 1774), p. 173; but cf. also William Cowper, “An Ode, Secundem Artem,” line 25, in Works of William Cowper, ed. Southey, London: Baldwin and Craddock, 1835), p. 331. I’ll stray,
And seek her footsteps in the flow’ry road.
Then come, my Muse, expand thine airy wing,
Should some Mæcenas88 Byword for a generous patron of literature or art derived from Gaius Cilnius Maecenas (65 BC-8BCE), patron of Horace and Virgil. patronize thy lays,
Thou in heroic numbers yet may sing,
And to the Cypress add the blooming Bays:
Then though thou tread Parnassus99 Mount Parnassus, home of the muses, and therefore shorthand here for poetry. rugged ways
Unled by science, up the sacred hill,
If Phœbus darts on thee propitious rays;
By him instructed, thou shalt sing with skill.
